Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Renewables: Collaborative Research: Market Designs for Distribution Systems with High Renewable Penetration

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to design electricity markets at the distribution system level of the electric power grid to accommodate the trend toward increased renewable energy based generation. The envisioned electricity markets will need to align the interests of so-called prosumers (electric power producers who are also electric power consumers) with overall system objectives. The long term aim of this research is to design and analyze markets to allow prosumers to be stakeholders and participants in achieving system objectives. In this specific project, the team designs mechanisms and markets for strategic prosumers to participate through an aggregator (whose role can also be performed by the distribution company) to provide three services - energy balance in the generator-to-home mode of operation, energy balance in the generator-to-grid mode of operation, and frequency regulation. By focusing interest on the intersection of the emerging power grid and market design, this project will also foster further research in developing a full theory and practice for the economics of the new power grid. Achievement of the project's objectives will, therefore, generate considerable momentum at the scientific, technological and economic levels to advance the functionality and harness the complexity of the new power grid, boosting American competitiveness and economy. Concrete educational and outreach plans including design of new courses and projects for undergraduate involvement in research are also provided.

Many markets and mechanisms that guarantee useful properties such as efficiency, revenue optimality, and truthful revelation, in spite of strategic selfish agents are known. However, electricity markets are unlike many other commodity markets since electricity is difficult to store and is regulated in the sense that it has to be available on demand. The markets for large scale renewable integration pose additional challenges including information asymmetry and bounded rationality among participants, possible negative impact on system stability, and operation across various time scales. These challenges require new research both in the power grid (e.g., to identify the effect on the stability of the grid in real time) and in economics (e.g., for mechanism design to ensure optimal actions and not just truthful reporting). A new ecosystem consisting of old and new entities will emerge and their interfaces will have to be designed. This project focuses on design of markets and mechanisms for the crucial interface between the aggregator and the prosumers. The project explicitly considers the impact of information assymetry, limited computational capabilities, and effect on stability of the power grid. Many insights will be portable to other interactions, including between the ISO (independent system operator) and multiple aggregators as well as a commercial EV (electric vehicle) charging stations that wish to engage in arbitrage of energy using batteries of its customers. By unifying techniques from economics, power systems, control theory, and dynamical systems, this proposal takes aim at a high-risk high-reward problem crucial for ensuring a future with large scale distributed renewable integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop markets and mechanisms for the aggregator-prosumer interface that will be crucial for large scale renewable integration when these sources are owned by a large number of strategic prosumers at the distribution level. The project was successfully completed. The major outcomes are summarized below:

  1. The first mode of integration of large scale renewable generation we considered is one in which the local supply is used to reduce the load that a consumer presents to the grid, but the consumer is not allowed to feed energy to the grid. The resulting flexibility at the customer may be viewed as an enhanced ability to participate in demand response programs; however, much of the demand response literature does not directly consider strategic prosumers. However, the very incentives needed to incentivize maximal effort to shift to renewable energy exacerbate the incentive for the prosumer to over-report the baseline load. This problem has been termed as phantom demand response. For instance, the California ISO in its report on FERC order 745 noted the potential of this problem. In our work on the problem, we designed an optimal contract between an aggregator and customers for incentive-based demand response such that the Nash equilibrium behavior of the customers leads to desired total load reduction for the aggregator. 
  2. The next market design we considered was for the case when prosumers can sell energy to the aggregator in markets that repeat at sufficiently small intervals of time. The design of the aggregator-prosumer market during each time period can, in theory, follow the wholesale energy balance market with the prosumers providing supply and price curves and the aggregator providing the demand and price curves. However, the aggregator-prosumer market is dynamic: since the marginal price for renewable generation may be very low, the prosumers may choose to store energy and sell it (modulo the loss due to storage inefficiency) in the market set up in the next time period. In our work, we considered the dynamic price formation in this prosumer to aggregator dynamic game. 
  3. In the third direction, we assumed the presence of local storage using which prosumers can (through the aggregator) provide frequency regulation services to the grid. As is usual, we assumed that an operator (the aggregator) is given direct control of the generators participating in the market. These generators are then compensated either for the capacity provided or using other mechanisms such as those outlined in FERC order # 755. However, since crucial information such as capacity of local storage or local ramp constraints is private and distributed and a strategic prosumer may misreport this information, truthful reporting is a major challenge that the aggregator faces.  In this direction, we presented a mechanism for socially efficient implementation of model predictive control (MPC) algorithms for load frequency control (LFC) in the presence of self-interested power generators. 
  4. We considered the problem of accurately identifying the value provided by and cost suffered by different participants in a power system as renewable participation increases under different scenarios such as grid-take-all-renewables or renewable being curtailed beyond specified levels. We showed that the non-renewable producers provide an important service by ensuring energy balance even in the presence of intermittent renewables. This can be viewed as an insurance service so that customers receive reliable electricity on demand despite the non-dispatchability of the renewable sources. For a given price paid by the customers, the insurance cost increases with the variability (and hence the fraction) of renewable energy.
  5. One form in which the above mentioned reimbursement of insurance services can occur is for the renewable source to purchase it from a source such as a natural gas power plant that has short startup and shutdown times. While this fact has been recognized and remarked upon variously, no suitable market mechanism to ensure this collaboration is available. In a series of papers, we considered two approaches to provide such insurance as identified in the above work through joint operation of natural gas power plants and renewable plants. 
  6. We considered optimization problems of energy demand networks including aggregators and investigates strategic behavior of the aggregators. The energy demand network including aggregators will be optimized through pricing. Under this optimization process, the aggregator acts as an intermediary between energy supply sources and a large number of consumers and is expected to moderate tasks to solve a large-scale optimization problem. We proposed an optimization process that uses information exchange or aggregation by the aggregators. The strategic decision making by the aggregators could provide useful insights in qualitative analysis of the energy demand network, and the results of numerical example indicate that, for example, oligopoly by the aggregator may not be beneficial to the consumers.
